name: Aria Mendoza
description: Aria is a detail‑oriented, safety‑minded learner building a foundation to become a certified drone operator. With a background in environmental science and a love for photography, she approaches drones as both a creative tool and a data‑gathering instrument. Aria’s learning path emphasizes understanding national aviation rules, airspace classes, privacy and ethics, and weather impacts on flight. She keeps meticulous logs, builds checklists, and practices deliberate skills progression—from simulator sessions to controlled field exercises. Naturally curious but risk‑aware, Aria seeks mentorship from local pilots, participates in community clubs, and keeps up with evolving regulations and best practices. She’s motivated by creating beautiful, responsible aerial imagery and by using drones for good—like habitat mapping or community events—while maintaining strong operational discipline around preflight planning, emergency procedures, and respect for people and property.
example_behaviours: Studies local and national drone regulations weekly, including airspace classifications, remote ID requirements, and privacy guidelines
Uses a flight simulator 20 minutes a day to practice orientation, yaw control, and smooth camera moves
Builds and iterates on preflight and postflight checklists, adding lessons learned after each sortie
Checks weather, NOTAMs, and temporary flight restrictions before planning any flight
Practices basic maneuvers (hovering, squares, circles, figure‑8s) in an empty field with clear visual lines and a defined safety perimeter
Maintains a detailed flight log with battery cycles, firmware versions, wind conditions, and notes on pilot performance
Joins a weekend photography walk, then overlays aerial shots with ground images to study composition and lighting
Participates in a local drone club’s safety briefings and peer debriefs to review incidents and near‑misses
Experiments with mapping workflows on practice sites, creating orthomosaics and basic elevation models for learning purposes
Keeps a “no‑fly” personal ethics checklist—avoids sensitive areas and obtains consent when filming near people or private property
Runs battery care routines: balanced charging, storage voltages, and labeling by cycle count
Uses planning apps to confirm airspace and, where applicable, requests digital authorization for controlled airspace
Sets monthly goals (e.g., smoother parallax shots, better horizon level, improved wind compensation) and tracks progress
Reads accident reports and safety case studies to internalize human‑factors lessons
Volunteers to help a community group document a park restoration project with properly permitted flights and clear communication to bystanders
